Yes, the cost of VR technology can be a significant barrier to its widespread adoption in mental health treatment, particularly for patients who cannot afford it. VR equipment can be expensive, and specialized VR software is often required to create the customized environments required for mental health therapy. 

This cost is a factor that may limit access to VR in some settings, such as in low-income or underfunded mental health clinics, rural or remote areas, and developing countries. Additionally, patients who do not have an understanding of technology or are not comfortable using it may struggle with using VR technology effectively.

However, as the technology continues to advance, VR equipment costs are expected to decrease, making it more accessible to patients and clinicians. Additionally, some mental health care providers and organizations are beginning to invest in VR technology as a way to expand their treatment capabilities, which may increase accessibility to patients.

Furthermore, there are initiatives and programs that offer low-cost or free access to VR technology for patients in need. For example, some research centers and universities offer free VR therapy sessions for study participants, and some companies have developed VR therapy apps that patients can access using their smartphones.

In conclusion, while the cost of VR technology is a barrier to its widespread adoption in mental health treatment, efforts are being made to make it more accessible to patients. As technology continues to advance, we can expect costs to decrease, making it easier for patients to access this innovative treatment.
